sen.j: 茶室（ちゃしつ）は、茶事の主催者（主人、亭主）が客を招き、茶を出してもてなすために造られる施設である。
sen.e: "Chashitsu" is a facility built for a host of tea ceremony (shujin) to invite and entertain guests with tea.
"Chashitsu" is a facility built for a tea ceremony host (shujin) to invite and entertain guests with tea.
"Chashitsu" is a facility built for a tea ceremony host (shujin) to invite and entertain guests with tea.

sen.j: 日本庭園の中に造り、露地を設けるのが一般的であったが、近年ではホテルや公会堂、商業ビルの一角などに造られることもある。
sen.e: Chashitsu used to be built in a Japanese garden usually with a pathway to it, but today they are built in various places: at hotels, in civic halls, and at a corner of commercial buildings.
Chashitsu used to be built in a Japanese garden usually with a pathway to it, but today they are built in various places: at hotels, in civic halls, and at the corner of some commercial buildings.
Chashitsu used to be built in a Japanese garden usually with a pathway to it, but today they are built in various places: at hotels, in civic halls, and at the corner of some commercial buildings.

sen.j: 茶道の稽古をしたり、茶を楽しむために炉が切ってある和室（畳のある部屋）も一般に茶室と呼ばれるが、本項では主に四畳半以下の草庵風茶室について述べる。
sen.e: Although a Japanese room (a tatami-matted room) that are installed with a built-in hearth to learn or enjoy a tea ceremony is often called Chashitsu, this section describs mainly soan-style (small grass-thatched hut) teahouse with four-and-a-half mats or less.

Although Japanese rooms (tatami-matted rooms) that are installed with a built-in hearth to learn or enjoy the tea ceremony are often called Chashitsu, this section describes mainly soan-style (small grass-thatched hut) teahouses with four-and-a-half mats or less.

Although Japanese rooms (tatami-matted rooms) that are installed with a built-in hearth to learn or enjoy the tea ceremony are often called Chashitsu, this section describes mainly soan-style (small grass-thatched hut) teahouses with four-and-a-half mats or less.

tit.cmt: 既出のため、括弧は削除しました。

sen.j: 草庵風茶室は、田舎屋風の素朴な材料（丸太、竹、土壁など）を使って造られた。
sen.e: Soan-stlye Chashitsu were built of simple materials (logs, bamboos, clay) as used in rural private homes.
Soan-stlye Chashitsu were built of simple materials (logs, bamboo, clay) as used in rural private homes.
Soan-style Chashitsu were built of simple materials (logs, bamboo, clay) as used in rural private homes.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 縁側からの採光を土壁でさえぎり、そこに必要に応じて「窓（下地窓、連子窓、突き上げ窓など）」をあけることにより光による自在な演出が可能となった。
sen.e: Light from engawa (veranda) is shielded by a plastered clay wall on which windows (shitaji mado, or a window in which the inner structure of plaster wall is shown; renji mado, or a window with lattice; tsukiage mado, or a skylight window on a ceiling that can be opened by a stick) are built to have an artistic cotrol of light.

Light from the engawa (veranda) is shielded by a plastered clay wall in which windows are set to enable artistic control of the light, such as shitaji mado, or a window in which the inner structure of the plaster wall is shown; renji mado, or a window with a lattice; tsukiage mado, or a skylight window in the ceiling that can be opened by a stick.

Light from the engawa (veranda) is shielded by a plastered clay wall in which windows are set to enable artistic control of the light, such as shitaji mado, or a window in which the inner structure of the plaster wall is shown; renji mado, or a window with a lattice; tsukiage mado, or a skylight window in the ceiling that can be opened by a stick.

sen.j: 一間を基本としていた床の間も部屋の広狭、構成に応じて四尺、五尺とバリエーションを増し、そのデザインも、「室床」「洞床」「壁床」「踏み込み床」など、多様な展開を見せる。
sen.e: Tokonoma (alcove) used to be one ken (1.8 m), but it is now varied in size, four or five shaku (1.2 or 1.5 m), depending on the room structure and its design has also wide variations: 'muro-doko' (a tokonoma plastered all over including the ceiling); 'hora-doko' (a cave-like tokonoma); 'kabe-doko' (tokonoma formed by only a wall); and 'fumikomi-doko' (a 'step-in' tokonoma) with its floor level being the same as that of the room.

The tokonoma (alcove) used to be one ken (1.8 m), but now varies in size around four or five shaku (1.2 or 1.5 m), depending on the room structure, and its design also varies widely, and may include 'muro-doko' (a tokonoma plastered all over including the ceiling), 'hora-doko' (a cave-like tokonoma), 'kabe-doko' (tokonoma formed by only a wall), or 'fumikomi-doko' (a 'step-in' tokonoma) with its floor level with the rest of the room.

The tokonoma (alcove) used to be one ken (1.8 meters), but now varies in size around four or five shaku (1.2 or 1.5 meters), depending on the room structure, and its design also varies widely, and may include 'muro-doko' (a tokonoma plastered all over including the ceiling), 'hora-doko' (a cave-like tokonoma), 'kabe-doko' (tokonoma formed by only a wall), or 'fumikomi-doko' (a 'step-in' tokonoma).

sen.j: 室内には中柱を立て亭主座と客座の結界とした。
sen.e: Nakabashira, or a small pillar standing inside the room makes a boundary between the host's seat and the guests' seats.
Nakabashira, or a small pillar standing inside the room, makes a boundary between the host's seat and the guests' seats.
Nakabashira, or a small pillar standing inside the room, makes a boundary between the host's seat and the guests' seats.

sen.j: こうして狭い空間の中に客と亭主が相対する、濃密な空間が生まれた。
sen.e: This setting helps to produce a spiritually rich space of the host and the guests.
This setting helps to produce a spiritually rich space between the host and the guests.
This setting helps to produce a spiritually rich space between the host and the guests.

sen.j: 足利義政が東山に建てた（慈照寺）東求堂には四畳半の部屋があり、茶室の元祖と言われることがある。
sen.e: Togudo of Jisho-ji Temple in Higashiyama area built by Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA has a 4.5 tatami-mat room, which is said to be the origin of the tea ceremony room.
Togudo in Jisho-ji Temple in the Higashiyama area, built by Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, has a four-and-a-half tatami-mat room, which is said to be the origin of the tea ceremony room.
Togudo in Jisho-ji Temple in the Higashiyama area, built by Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, has a four-and-a-half tatami-mat room, which is said to be the origin of the tea ceremony room.

sen.j: また、村田珠光が市中の草庵として四畳半の茶室を造った。
sen.e: Later, Juko MURATA created a 4.5 mat tea ceremony room as a small grass-thatched hut in town.
Later, Juko MURATA created a four-and-a-half mat tea ceremony room as a small grass-thatched hut in the city.
Later, Juko MURATA created a four-and-a-half mat tea ceremony room as a small grass-thatched hut in the city.

sen.j: 茶室を独自の様式として完成させたのが千利休である。
sen.e: Sen no Rikyu established his unique form of Chashitsu.
Sen no Rikyu established a unique form of Chashitsu.
SEN no Rikyu established a unique form of Chashitsu.
sen.cmt: 名字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 利休は侘び茶の精神を突き詰め、それまでは名物を一つも持たぬ侘び茶人の間でしか行われなかった二畳、三畳の小間を採り入れ、にじり口をあけた二畳の茶室を造った。
sen.e: Rikyu made the pursuit of spirit of Wabi-cha (combination of Zen Buddhism and the way of drinking tea), and adopting koma (small tea rooms) of two mats or three mats that had been only used by Wabi-cha masters who owned no valuable tea utensils, he finally created a two-mat tea room with nijiriguchi (a cram-through doorway).

Rikyu pursued the spirit of Wabi-cha (the combination of Zen Buddhism and the way of drinking tea), and adopted koma (small tea rooms) of two mats or three mats that had only been used by Wabi-cha masters who owned no valuable tea utensils, and he finally created a two-mat tea room with a nijiriguchi (a cram-through doorway).
sen.cmt: 「made the pursuit of」→「pursued the」, 「the」挿入, 「adopting」→「adopted」, 「been only」→「only been」, 「and」挿入,「a」挿入, 'a cram-through doorway' has a bit of a negative nuance, so it might be better to put 'a tiny doorway'.
sen.e: Rikyu pursued the spirit of Wabi-cha (the combination of Zen Buddhism and the way of drinking tea), and adopted koma (small tea rooms) of two mats or three mats that had only been used by Wabi-cha masters who owned no valuable tea utensils, and he finally created a two-mat tea room with a nijiriguchi (a cram-through doorway).

sen.j: 茶室待庵（国宝）は千利休の作とも言われるが、侘び茶の境地をよく示している。
sen.e: Chashitsu Taian (a National Treasure), which is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu, expresses the spirit of Wabi-cha.
Chashitsu Taian (a National Treasure), which is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu, expresses the spirit of Wabi-cha.
Chashitsu Taian (a National Treasure), which is said to have been created by SEN no Rikyu, expresses the spirit of Wabi-cha.

sen.j: にじり口は、千利休が河内枚方の淀川河畔で漁夫が船小屋に入る様子を見てヒントを得た、とされる。
sen.e: Rikyu is said to have created nijiriguchi inspired by seeing how a fisherman entered a boathouse on a riverfront of Yodo-gawa River in Kawachi Hirakata.
Rikyu is said to have created nijiriguchi inspired by seeing how a fisherman entered a boathouse on the riverfront at Yodo-gawa River in Kawachi Hirakata.
Rikyu is said to have created nijiriguchi inspired by seeing how a fisherman entered a boathouse on the riverfront at the Yodo-gawa River in Kawachi Hirakata.
sen.cmt: "Yodo-gawa River"→"the Yodo-gawa River"に変更しました。

sen.j: しかし、にじり口の原型とみられる入り口は、武野紹鴎の時代の古図にも見られ、また商家の大戸に明けられた潜りなど同類の試みは多種見られることから、利休の発明とは言えない。
sen.e: However, doorways that can be considered prototypes of nijiriguchi appear on old drawings at the time of Joo TAKENO (a merchant tea master in mid-15th century), and many similar designs such as a tiny door built in a large door of a merchant house had existed, so it was not Rikyu's invention.

However, doorways that can be considered prototypes of nijiriguchi appear on old drawings of the time of Joo TAKENO (a merchant tea master in the mid-15th century), and many similar designs such as a tiny door built in a large door in merchant houses existed previously, so it was not Rikyu's invention.
sen.cmt: 「at」→「of」, 「the」挿入,「of a merchant house」→「in merchant houses」, 「had existed」→「existed previously」
sen.e: However, doorways that can be considered prototypes of nijiriguchi appear on old drawings of the time of Joo TAKENO, and many similar designs such as a tiny door built in a large door in merchant houses existed previously, so it was not Rikyu's invention.
sen.cmt: 武野紹鴎の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 利休は一方で、秀吉の依頼で黄金の茶室を造っている。
sen.e: Rikyu also built a golden tea room following Hideyoshi's order.
Rikyu also built a golden tea room to Hideyoshi's orders.
Rikyu also built a golden tea room to Hideyoshi's orders.

sen.j: これは解体して持ち運びできるように造られていた。
sen.e: It could be disassembled and moved to different places.
It could be disassembled and moved to different places.
It could be disassembled and moved to different places.

sen.j: 黄金の茶室は秀吉の俗悪趣味として批判されることが多いが、草庵の法に従って三畳の小間であり、それなり洗練されたものも持っている。
sen.e: Although this golden tea room has been criticized as Hideyoshi's vulgar taste, it was a small room of three mats following the rule of soan-type and had some sophisticated taste.
Although this golden tea room has been criticized as an example of Hideyoshi's vulgar taste, it was a small room of three mats following the rule of the soan-type and had some sophisticated elements.
Although this golden tea room has been criticized as an example of Hideyoshi's vulgar taste, it was a small room of three mats following the rule of the soan-type and had some sophisticated elements.

sen.j: 黄金の茶室も利休の茶の一面を示しているという見方もある。
sen.e: An opinion says that this golden tea room was one of the aspects of Rikyu's form of tea philosophy.
One view is that this golden tea room was one of the aspects of Rikyu's form of tea philosophy.
One view is that this golden tea room was one of the aspects of Rikyu's form of tea philosophy.

sen.j: 古田重然、小堀遠州らも茶室を造っている。
sen.e: Shigenari FURUTA and Enshu KOBORI also created Chashitsu of their own type.
Shigenari FURUTA and Enshu KOBORI also created Chashitsu of their own type.
Shigenari FURUTA and Enshu KOBORI also created Chashitsu of their own type.

sen.j: 茶室は小さな空間であるが、様々なパターンがあり、多様な展開を見せている。
sen.e: Being a small space, Chashitsu can have a variety of designs, and a number of types of them were built.
Being a small space, Chashitsu can have a variety of designs, and a number of types of them were built.
Being a small space, Chashitsu can have a variety of designs, and a number of types of them were built.

sen.j: 利休の孫宗旦は究極の侘びを追求して、利休が試みてすぐ廃した一畳台目という極小の茶室を生み出した。
sen.e: Rikyu's grand son Sotan explored Wabi to the extreme, and created the smallest Chashitsu called "Ichijo-Daime" with one guest mat and a short mat for the host, which Rikyu had once tried to make but given up.

Rikyu's grandson Sotan explored Wabi to the extreme, and created the smallest Chashitsu called "Ichijo-Daime" with one guest mat and a short mat for the host, which Rikyu had once tried to make but given up.

Rikyu's grandson Sotan explored Wabi to the extreme, and created the smallest Chashitsu called "Ichijo-Daime" with one guest mat and a short mat for the host, which Rikyu had once tried to make but given up.

sen.j: これに対して、古田織部、小堀遠州、織田有楽斎、金森宗和ら大名茶人は、武家の格式を持つ書院風茶室や小間と言えど三畳前後のゆとりのある茶室を生み出した。
sen.e: Compared with this, Oribe FURUTA, Enshu KOBORI, Urakusai ODA, and Sowa KANAMORI, who were feudal lords and tea masters, created samurai class shoin-style Chashitsu, or comfortable Chashitsu of a small room as large as three mats.

Compared with this, Oribe FURUTA, Enshu KOBORI, Urakusai ODA, and Sowa KANAMORI, who were feudal lords and tea masters, created samurai class shoin-style Chashitsu, or comfortable Chashitsu with a small room as large as three mats.

Compared with this, Oribe FURUTA, Enshu KOBORI, Urakusai ODA, and Sowa KANAMORI, who were feudal lords and tea masters, created samurai class shoin-style Chashitsu, or comfortable Chashitsu with a small room as large as three mats.

sen.j: 千家歴代もそれぞれに新たな茶室を好んでいるが、その試みは必ずしも宗旦が目指した侘びに徹したものとはなっていない。
sen.e: Each generation of the SEN family has preferred a new type of Chashitsu, but not to the extent of Wabi that Sotan sought.
Each generation of the SEN family has preferred a new type of Chashitsu, but not to the extent of Wabi that Sotan sought.
Each generation of the SEN family has preferred a new type of Chashitsu, but not to the extent of Wabi that Sotan sought.

sen.j: 茶室は小規模でもあり、解体して他の場所で再建することも比較的容易である。
sen.e: Since Chashitsu are small, they can relatively easily be disassembled and rebuilt at a different place.
Since Chashitsu are small, they can relatively easily be disassembled and rebuilt at a different place.
Since Chashitsu are small, they can relatively easily be disassembled and rebuilt at a different place.

sen.j: 現に如庵（国宝）は、京都市の建仁寺から東京の三井家、大磯町の三井家別荘、犬山市の名古屋鉄道有楽苑、と度々移築されている。
sen.e: In fact, Joan (a tea house, a National Treasure) was moved from Kennin-ji Temple in Kyoto City to the MITSUI family in Tokyo, and then their villa in Oiso Machi, and finally rebuilt at Meitetsu Urakuen in Inuyama City.

In fact, Joan (a tea house, and a National Treasure) was moved from Kennin-ji Temple in Kyoto City to the MITSUI family in Tokyo, and then their villa in Oiso Machi, and finally rebuilt at Meitetsu Urakuen in Inuyama City.

In fact, Joan (a tea house, and a National Treasure) was moved from Kennin-ji Temple in Kyoto City to the MITSUI family in Tokyo, and then their villa in Oiso-machi, and finally rebuilt at Meitetsu Urakuen in Inuyama City.

sen.j: また「写し」と称して、名席と評される茶室を模して建てられることもしばしばある。
sen.e: Chashitsu are often built in imitation of a highly valued Chashitsu, a practice of which is called "utsushi", or imitation.
Chashitsu are often built in imitation of a highly valued Chashitsu, a practice which is called "utsushi", or imitation.
Chashitsu are often built in imitation of a highly valued Chashitsu, a practice which is called 'utsushi,' or imitation.

sen.j: 仮に茶室が単独でポツンと建てられていたら殺風景なものである。
sen.e: If Chashitsu were standing alone in an open space, it would look bleak.
If a Chashitsu stood alone in an open space, it would look bleak.
If a Chashitsu stood alone in an open space, it would look bleak.

sen.j: 茶室に至るまでの空間の演出が大切である。
sen.e: It is important to entertain guests in the space of pathway that leads to Chashitsu.
It is important to entertain guests in the space filled by the pathway that leads to Chashitsu.
It is important to entertain guests in the space filled by the pathway that leads to Chashitsu.

sen.j: 客がいきなり茶室に通されることはなく、まず寄り付きや座敷などへ案内される。
sen.e: Guests are not introduced directly to Chashitsu, but are first ushered to yoritsuki (a waiting shelter of the outer garden) or zashiki (a reception room with tatami mats).
Guests are not introduced directly to Chashitsu, but are first ushered to a yoritsuki (a waiting shelter of the outer garden) or a zashiki (a reception room with tatami mats).
Guests are not introduced directly to Chashitsu, but are first ushered to a yoritsuki (a waiting shelter of the outer garden) or a zashiki (a reception room with tatami mats).

sen.j: 庭へ出て小さな門をくぐる。
sen.e: They step into the garden and walk through a small gate.
They step into the garden and walk through a small gate.
They step into the garden and walk through a small gate.

sen.j: 茶室までの通り道は、飛び石を配した露地となっていて亭主の心遣いにより打ち水が打たれている。
sen.e: Stepping stones are laid out along the garden path to Chashitsu, and the guests notice that the host has cared to water the path.
Stepping stones are laid out along the garden path to the Chashitsu, and the guests notice that the host has cared to water the path.
Stepping stones are laid out along the garden path to the Chashitsu, and the guests notice that the host has cared to water the path.

sen.j: 途中の待合に腰掛があり、ここでしばらく待つ。
sen.e: There is machiai (a waiting area in the inner garden) on the pathway with seats, where the guests wait for the host for a while.
There is machiai (a waiting area in the inner garden) on the pathway, with seats where the guests wait for the host for a while.
There is machiai (a waiting area in the inner garden) on the pathway, with seats where the guests wait for the host for a while.

sen.j: 迎えでた亭主の合図に従い客は茶室へと向かう。
sen.e: The host comes out to welcome the guests into the Chashitsu.
The host then comes out to welcome the guests into the Chashitsu.
The host then comes out to welcome the guests into the Chashitsu.

sen.j: 茶室の前につくばいがあり、ここで手水を使う。
sen.e: The guests do "chozu", or ritually purify themselves by pouring some water over their hand using tsukubai (a tiny purifying basin) in front of the Chashitsu.
The guests do "chozu", or ritually purify themselves by pouring some water over their hands using a tsukubai (a tiny purifying basin) in front of the Chashitsu.
The guests do "chozu", or ritually purify themselves by pouring some water over their hands using a tsukubai (a tiny purifying basin) in front of the Chashitsu.

sen.j: 茶室には、にじり口という小さな入口から、頭をかがめて体を入れる。
sen.e: The guests enter the Chashitsu through nijiriguchi with heads down.
The guests enter the Chashitsu through the nijiriguchi with heads down.
The guests enter the Chashitsu through the nijiriguchi with heads down.

sen.j: にじり口に入ってまず目に入るのが床の間である。
sen.e: As they go through the nijiriguchi, they first see Tokonoma.
As they go through the nijiriguchi, they first see the Tokonoma.
As they go through the nijiriguchi, they first see the Tokonoma.

sen.j: 墨蹟窓からの光に照らされた床には、四季に合わせた掛け軸、花があしらわれている。
sen.e: Kakejiku (a hanging scroll) and flowers representing the season are arranged on the tokonoma which is illuminated by light from bokuseki-mado (a window on the side wall of an alcove used to provide light).

A kakejiku (hanging scroll) and flowers representing the season are arranged on the tokonoma which is illuminated by light from a bokuseki-mado (a window on the side wall of the alcove used to provide light).

A kakejiku (hanging scroll) and flowers representing the season are arranged on the tokonoma which is illuminated by light from a bokuseki-mado (a window on the side wall of the alcove used to provide light).

sen.j: 通常床前が上座であり正客席となる。
sen.e: A main guest usually sits in front of tokonoma or on kamiza (a mat at the highest ranked position).
The main guest usually sits in front of the tokonoma or on a kamiza (a mat placed at the highest ranked position).
The main guest usually sits in front of the tokonoma or on a kamiza (a mat placed at the highest ranked position).

sen.j: 夏には風炉が置かれ、冬には炉が切られ、そこが亭主の座る手前座である。
sen.e: The host sits on temaeza (a tea host's mat), before which furo (a portable brazier) is placed in summer, and a hearth is built in winter.
The host sits on a temaeza (a tea host's mat), before which a furo (a portable brazier) is placed in summer, and a hearth is built in winter.
The host sits on a temaeza (a tea host's mat), before which a furo (a portable brazier) is placed in summer, and a hearth is built in winter.

sen.j: 手前のための明り取りとして風炉先には下地窓が開けられている。
sen.e: Close to the furo, there is shitajimado to light the host's hands.
Close to the furo, there is a shitajimado to light the host's hands.
Close to the furo, there is a shitajimado to light the host's hands.

sen.j: 客が着座すると亭主が勝手口から出てきて挨拶をし茶事が始まる。
sen.e: All the guests are seated, when the host comes in at katteguchi (a side door, or a host's entrance)
All the guests are seated when the host comes in at the katteguchi (a side door, or the host's entrance)
All the guests are seated when the host comes in at the katteguchi (a side door, or the host's entrance)

sen.j: 天井は低く、窓からの光も必要最小限に絞られて、主客ともに茶事に集中する。
sen.e: The ceiling is low and minimum light comes in from the windows, which helps the host and guests focus on the tea ceremony.
The ceiling is low and minimum light comes in from the windows, which helps the host and guests focus on the tea ceremony.
The ceiling is low and minimum light comes in from the windows, which helps the host and guests focus on the tea ceremony.

sen.j: 懐石を戴いた後一旦露地に退出するが、また茶室に戻り、まず濃茶を一同回し飲み、ついで薄茶を味わった後、客はこの一期一会の場から静かに退出する。
sen.e: Following kaiseki (a light meal), the guests retire to the garden for a short break, then return to the Chashitsu to drink koicha (thick tea) passing a bowl once, and after enjoying usucha (thin tea), the guests leave peacefully acknowledging each other one last time.

Following kaiseki (a light meal), the guests retire to the garden for a short break, then return to the Chashitsu to drink koicha (thick tea) turning the bowl once, and after enjoying usucha (thin tea) the guests leave, peacefully acknowledging each other one last time.

Following kaiseki (a light meal), the guests retire to the garden for a short break before returning to the Chashitsu to drink koicha (a strong green tea) and then usucha (a weak green tea), with each guest taking a drink from the bowl before it is passed on to the next guest; the guests then leave, quietly acknowledging each other one last time.
sen.cmt: Explaining exactly how the bowl is passed around would result in an overly long sentence so I have used the passive to keep this vague (and therefore short). A more specific explanation would be best, I think, but it would probably have to be broken up into two sentences such as the following.Following kaiseki (a light meal), the guests retire to the garden for a short break, return to the Chashitsu to drink koicha (thick tea) and then usucha (a weak green tea); they then leave, quietly acknowledging each other one last time. When koicha is served, each guest receives the bowl of tea directly from the host, but when the usucha is served, the first guest receives the bowl of tea from the host, takes a small drink, and then passes it to the next guest, with this being repeated until all the guests have taken a drink from the bowl.

sen.j: にじり口には頭を下げなければ入れないので、貴人を迎える場合のため、にじり口とは別に貴人口（立ったまま入れる普通の障子戸）を設けることも多い。
sen.e: Because guests have to lower their heads to go through nijiriguchi, kijinguchi (an ordinary walk-in paper sliding door) is often built in addition to nijiriguchi to welcome high ranked people.

Because guests have to lower their heads to go through the nijiriguchi, a kijinguchi (an ordinary walk-in paper sliding door) is often built in addition to the nijiriguchi to welcome high ranking people.

Because guests have to lower their heads to go through the nijiriguchi, a kijinguchi (an ordinary walk-in paper sliding door) is often built in addition to the nijiriguchi to welcome high ranking people.

sen.j: 給仕のために勝手口とは別に給仕口をもうける事もある。
sen.e: In addition to katteguchi, kyujiguchi is sometimes built to bring in meals.
In addition to a katteguchi, a kyujiguchi is sometimes built to bring in meals.
In addition to a katteguchi, a kyujiguchi is sometimes built to bring in meals.

sen.j: 記事露地も参照の事。
sen.e: Also refer to an article about roji.
Also refer to an article about roji.
Also refer to an article about roji.

tit.e: Values from the viewpoint of architectural history
Significance from the viewpoint of architectural history
Significance from the viewpoint of architectural history

sen.j: 最小の空間の中に豊かな広がりが与えられており、日本建築の特色あるジャンルになっている
sen.e: It represents a unique study field of Japanese architecture, because Chashitsu provides a rich spiritual space in a minimum physical space.
They represent a unique field of study within Japanese architecture, because Chashitsu provide a rich spiritual space in minimum physical space.
sen.cmt: Singular changed to plural. 「study field of」→「field of study within」, 「a」削除
sen.e: They represent a unique field of study within Japanese architecture, because Chashitsu provide a rich spiritual space in minimum physical space.

sen.j: 住宅建築に影響を与え、いわゆる数寄屋造りを生んだ
sen.e: It made an influence on architecture of residence to create so called sukiya-zukuri.
It had an influence on residential architecture, and led to so called sukiya-zukuri.
sen.cmt: 「made」→「had」, 「architecture of residence to create」→「residential architecture, and led to」
sen.e: It had an influence on residential architecture, and led to so called sukiya-zukuri style (a residence style influenced by teahouse architecture)
sen.cmt: 数寄屋造りの補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 下記のうち、国宝に指定されている待庵・如庵・密庵の三棟が特に著名である。
sen.e: Taian, Joan and Mittan, all of which are National Treasures, are outstanding among the following Chashitsu:
Taian, Joan and Mittan, all of which are National Treasures, are outstanding examples among the following Chashitsu:
